å‰è¨€

æœ€è¿‘æƒ³ä¾†çŒå€‹ Python 3 ï¼Œå»ç™¼ç¾ Homebrew ç‰ˆæœ¬å¥½åƒå¤ªèˆŠäº†ã€‚

å¤ªä»¤äººæ²®å–ªäº†ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯æˆ‘æ±ºå®šä¾†è·‘å€‹ brew update

/usr/local must be writable?

Error: /usr/local must be writable!

è›¤ï¼Ÿæˆ‘æœ‰çœ‹éŒ¯ã„‡ï¼Ÿæˆ‘æ˜æ˜è¨˜å¾— Homebrew ä¸ç”¨ /usr/local æ¬Šé™çš„å•Šï¼Ÿï¼Ÿï¼Ÿ

sudo chown -R $(whoami) /usr/local

ä¹‹å¾Œå†åŸ·è¡Œä¸€æ¬¡ brew update ï¼Œçœ‹æ¨£å­æ˜¯æˆåŠŸäº†ï¼Œä¸éåˆè¢«å˜²è«·äº†ä¸€æ¬¡â‹¯â‹¯

Homebrew no longer needs to have ownership of /usr/local. If you wish you can
return /usr/local to its default ownership with:
  sudo chown root:wheel /usr/local

Homebrew ğŸº ä½ åœ¨è·Ÿæˆ‘é–‹ç©ç¬‘å—ï¼Ÿ (â•¯Â°â–¡Â°ï¼‰â•¯ï¸µ â”»â”â”»

Thereâ€™s no such thing as â€œroot users.â€ â€œrootâ€ is a single user (user id 0). You can enable account login for the root user as described in that support article, but the root user always exists either way.

By contrast, â€œadminâ€ is a group. Users who are members of the admin group are characterized by their write access to /Applications, their ability to use â€œsudo,â€ and their ability to install software.

By default, brew is designed around the idea that the brew prefix (/usr/local) and all of its contents will be writable by all members of the admin group. Various things (usually nothing done by brew itself) can cause one or more things in /usr/local to end up not being writable by all admin users. The commands above recursively modify (if needed) the entries within /usr/local to ensure that the group assigned to each entry is admin, and that the admin group has write access to each entry.

sudo chmod -R g+w /usr/local

wonâ€™t be sufficient if a file or directory has group wheel, since admin users are usually not members of group wheel. The command would indeed ensure writability for members of wheel, but that doesnâ€™t help your user if itâ€™s a member of admin but not a member of wheel. So you also have to set the group of the file to be admin in order for g+w to actually make any difference.

$

There some Amoebas on the line with integer length and face to origin. A-Mi-Ba and B-Mi-Ba are playing with Amoebas in turns. A-Mi-Ba goes first.

The game is as following :

  1. Skip this step or choose an Amoeba and cut it into two pieces. Each of piece will be a new Amoeba. The length of new Amoeba should be an integer. Both of them will face to origin.
  2. Put a Yakeli-Food in front of one Amoeba in empty cell. The Amoeba will eat the Yakeli-Food and move one unit.

The game ended when nobody can move. It means that there only one Amoeba and itâ€™s head is in front of origin.

The loser is the player who canâ€™t move. He will be eaten by the Amoeba! Can you tell them who will be the winner?

entry.title: NEERC 2009, Northern, Problem E. Enigmatic Device
entry.content:
Latest Update: 2016-10-09 06:16:15

Description

Yes, it happened! The first contact! Aliens will visit the Earth in $2010$! And they promised to bring an enigmatic device which cannot be constructed using existing Earth technologies. Most of the scientists of the world think so! All newspapers already published their leading articles about it.

This device will accept an integer sequence $\{ a_i \} $ as its initial input. After that, it can perform the following two operations:

  1. Take an interval $[l; r]$ and perform $a_i$ â† $a_i^2$ $mod$ $2010$ for all $a_i$ such that $l \leq i \leq r$.
  2. Take an interval $[l; r]$ and output the sum of all $a_i$ such that $l \leq i \leq r$. Note that the sum is not taken modulo $2010$.

The amazing thing about this device is that it is able to perform $50000$ operations of this kind with a sequence of $50000$ numbers within $3$ seconds. Nobody could do it before!

But Roman does not believe in aliens and thinks that it is only a great hoax made by somebody just to win another million bucks on the stock exchange. His goal is to prove this. So he hired you to write a program to simulate this device.

Given an integer sequence ai and a sequence of operations, write a program which simulates the behaviour of the strange alien device.

Input Format

The first line of the input contains the length of the sequence $n$ ($1\leq n\leq 50000$). The second line contains n numbers ai forming the initial sequence ($0\leq a_i\leq 2009$). The third line contains the number of operations $m$ ($1\leq m\leq 50000$). The rest of file contains m lines, each describing one operation. The $j$-th operation is described by its kind $k_j$ (â€˜1â€™ for squaring, â€˜2â€™ for calculating the sum), followed by two integers $l_j$ and $r_j$ ($1\leq l_j\leq r_j\leq n$).

Output Format

For each operation of the second kind, write their output on the separate line, in order they appear in the input.

Sample Input

Sample Output

Codeforces2009-2010 ACM-ICPC, NEERC, Northern Subregional Contest

Solution

ã€€ã€€çœ‹åˆ°é¡Œç›®è¦æ±‚å€é–“æ›´æ–°å’ŒæŸ¥è©¢ï¼Œä¸é›£æƒ³åˆ°æ˜¯ç·šæ®µæ¨¹ã€‚ä½†é€™é¡Œçš„æ›´æ–°æ˜¯å¹³æ–¹ï¼Œå…‰æ˜¯å¹³æ–¹å°±ä¸çŸ¥é“è¦æ€éº¼å€é–“æ›´æ–°ï¼Œé€™è£¡éœ€è¦è§€å¯Ÿå¹¾å€‹æ€§è³ªï¼š

  • 2010 æ˜¯åˆæˆæ•¸ï¼Œæ ¹æ“šç¶“é©—æ³•å‰‡æˆ‘å€‘çŸ¥é“åˆæˆæ•¸çš„ç’°é€šå¸¸æ¯”è¼ƒå°ã€‚ï¼ˆè­‰æ˜å¾…è£œï¼‰
  • ç”±ä¸Šä¸€é …æˆ‘å€‘å¯ä»¥å¤§è†½åœ°æ¸¬è©¦ï¼Œç™¼ç¾é™¤äº† $a$ å’Œ $a^2$ ä»¥å¤–ï¼Œå¾Œé¢çš„å¹³æ–¹é‹ç®—æ¯åæ¬¡æœƒå¾ªç’°ä¸€æ¬¡ã€‚

ã€€ã€€åˆ©ç”¨ä¸Šè¿°æ€§è³ªï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘å¯ä»¥å…ˆé è™•ç† $\{ a_i, a_i^2, a_i^{2^2}, a_i^{2^3}, â€¦, a_i^{2^{12}} \} $ ï¼Œé€™æ¨£ç•¶æˆ‘å€‘è¦å°‡ $[l, n]$ å€é–“çš„æ¯å€‹å…ƒç´ å¹³æ–¹æ™‚ï¼Œåªè¦å°‡é ˆæ›´æ–°çš„å€é–“å­æ¨¹æ»¾å‹•ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œä¸¦æ›´æ–°å…¶æ‡¶æƒ°æ¨™è¨˜å³å¯ã€‚

entry.title: ECNA 2015 Problem G . Tray Bien
entry.content:
Latest Update: 2016-09-15 04:41:31

Description

ã€€ã€€AndrÃ© Claude Marzipan is the head chef at the French restaurant Le Chaud Chien. He owns a vast number of baking trays, which come in two sizes: 1 foot by 1 foot, and 1 foot by 2 feet. He stores them along 3-foot deep shelves of various lengths. For example, on a shelf that is 5 feet long, he might store baking trays in either of the two ways shown below:

ã€€ã€€Of course, there are many more than just these two ways, and in his off hours AndrÃ© often wondershow many different ways he can place trays on a given shelf. AndrÃ© is a bit of un maniaque du rangement (neat freak), so he insists that the trays are always aligned along the two axes defined by the shelf edges, that the edges of the trays are always 1 foot multiples away from any edge, and that no portion of a tray extends beyond the shelf. The matter is complicated by the fact that often there are locations on the shelf where he does not want to put any baking trays, due to leaks above the shelf, dents in the shelfâ€™s surface, etc. Since AndrÃ© is more adept at cuisine than counting, he needs a little help.

Input Format

ã€€ã€€The input consists of two lines: the first line will contain two integers $m, n$, where $1 â‰¤ m â‰¤ 24$ indicates the length of the shelf (which is always 3-feet deep) and $n$ indicates the number of bad locations on the shelf. The next line will contain $n$ coordinate pairs $x, y$ indicating the locations where trays should not be placed, where $0 < x < m$ and $0 < y < 3$. No location will have integer coordinates and coordinates are specified to the nearest hundredth. If $n = 0$, this second line will be blank.

Output Format

ã€€ã€€Output the number of ways that trays could be placed on the shelf.

Sample Input 1

Sample Output 1

Sample Input 2

Sample Output 2

CodeforcesECNA2015

ã€€ã€€æšèˆ‰æ¯ä¸€ç¨®å¡«æ»¿ç¬¬$i$è¡Œä¸¦å°‡ç¬¬$i+1$è¡Œæ’æˆç¬¬$j$ç¨®æ’åˆ—çš„æ–¹æ³•æ•¸ï¼Œåœ¨æ­¤ç‰¹åˆ¥åšé™åˆ¶ï¼š

  • æ”¾ç½®æ‰˜ç›¤ä¸å¯è¶…å‡ºç¬¬$i+1$è¡Œï¼Œä¿æŒç¬¬$i+2$è¡Œç‚ºç©ºã€‚
  • æ‰˜ç›¤ä¸€å®šè¦æ”¾åœ¨ç¬¬$i+1$è¡Œï¼Œå³è‹¥ç¬¬$i$è¡Œæœ‰ç©ºä½å‰‡è©²åˆ—åªèƒ½æ”¾$1\times2$çš„æ‰˜ç›¤ï¼Œæ©«è·¨ç¬¬$i$è¡Œèˆ‡ç¬¬$i+1$è¡Œã€‚

ã€€ã€€$T=\begin{bmatrix}

  1. DFS Tree çš„æ ¹ç¯€é»æœ‰è¶…éä¸€æ¢ Tree Edge æ™‚ï¼Œæ ¹ç¯€é»å¿…ç‚º APã€‚
  2. DFS Tree ä¸Šçš„ä»»æ„éæ ¹ç¯€é» $u$ çš„å…¶ä¸­ $1$ æ£µå­æ¨¹ä¸Šæ²’æœ‰ Back Edge é€šå¾€ $u$ çš„ç¥–å…ˆå€‘æ™‚ï¼Œ$u$ å¿…ç‚º APã€‚

    ã€€ã€€åœ¨æ­¤æˆ‘å€‘å®šç¾©å…©å€‹è®Šæ•¸ï¼š${dfn}_{u}$ èˆ‡ ${low}_{u}$ã€‚
